verses.text: The word that Jeremiah the prophet spoke to Baruch son of Neriah, when he wrote these words in a book at Jeremiah’s dictation, in the fourth year of Jehoiakim son of Josiah, king of Judah:
verses.comment: This introduction identifies Baruch as Jeremiah’s faithful scribe, recording the prophecy at a pivotal moment in Judah's history. The careful preservation and transmission of God's word prefigures the importance of apostolic tradition alongside Scripture (cf. 2 Thess. 2:15).

verses.text: Thus says the LORD, the God of Israel, to you, Baruch:
verses.comment: God personally addresses Baruch, showing a direct and intimate relationship between the LORD and those who serve through ministry. The phrase 'God of Israel' emphasizes continuity with the faith of the patriarchs and God's covenant fidelity.

verses.text: You said, 'Woe is me! For the LORD has added sorrow to my pain; I am weary with my groaning, and I find no rest.'
verses.comment: Baruch’s lament echoes the Psalms and the cry of faithful servants burdened by suffering. This reflects the spiritual reality of sharing in the sufferings of those called to proclaim God's truth (see Rom. 8:17).

verses.text: Thus you shall say to him, 'The LORD says this: See, what I have built, I am tearing down; and what I have planted, I am uprooting—even this entire land.'
verses.comment: God’s sovereign authority to build up and tear down nations highlights His active governance and the consequences of covenant unfaithfulness. The imagery of planting and uprooting also appears in the teaching of Christ regarding the kingdom (see Matt. 15:13).

verses.text: And you, do you seek great things for yourself? Do not seek them, for I am bringing disaster upon all flesh, declares the LORD. But wherever you go, I will give you your life as a prize.
verses.comment: Baruch is exhorted to humility and detachment from worldly ambition. The promise of life mirrors Christ’s teaching that true reward comes through self-denial and faithfulness. Spiritual perseverance and sacrificial obedience secure eternal life (cf. Mk. 8:35).
